user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_open_:
```c
static int lfs_dir_open_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, const char *path) {
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &dir->m, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }

    if (lfs_tag_type3(tag) != LFS_TYPE_DIR) {
        return LFS_ERR_NOTDIR;
    }

    lfs_block_t pair[2];
    if (lfs_tag_id(tag) == 0x3ff) {
        // handle root dir separately
        pair[0] = lfs->root[0];
        pair[1] = lfs->root[1];
    } else {
        // get dir pair from parent
        lfs_stag_t res = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &dir->m, LFS_MKTAG(0x700, 0x3ff, 0),
                LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_STRUCT, lfs_tag_id(tag), 8), pair);
        if (res < 0) {
            return res;
        }
        lfs_pair_fromle32(pair);
    }

    // fetch first pair
    int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, pair);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // setup entry
    dir->head[0] = dir->m.pair[0];
    dir->head[1] = dir->m.pair[1];
    dir->id = 0;
    dir->pos = 0;

    // add to list of mdirs
    dir->type = LFS_TYPE_DIR;
    lfs_mlist_append(lfs, (struct lfs_mlist *)dir);

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only place in this function that can modify a function parameter (the pointer variable itself) is where the address of the parameter 'path' is taken and passed to another function. Passing &path allows the callee to change the value of the parameter variable 'path' in this function, which would violate Rule 17.8. All other modifications in the function write to objects pointed to by parameters (e.g., dir->head, dir->id, dir->pos, dir->type, lfs->root, dir->m), which is permitted by the rule. There are no direct assignments to the pointer parameters 'lfs' or 'dir' (no statements like lfs = ... or dir = ...), and other address-of usages (e.g., &dir->m) take the address of a member object, not the parameter variable itself. Local arrays and temporaries (pair, tag, res, err) are local and do not modify the parameter variables. Therefore no other fragments need investigation for Rule 17.8.
